LINE.translation: In the seventh month of A.D. 607, a messenger from Japan named Ono no Imoko arrived at the palace in Changan, the capital of China.

LINE.translation: After taking from his pocket a letter from the government he had carefully carried through the long journey over the ocean, he slowly began to read.

STORY.LINE:

LINE.translation: "I, Emperor of the Land of the Rising Sun, send this letter to the Emperor of the Land of the Setting Sun. I trust you are well...."

STORY.LINE:

LINE.translation: That was the first line of a letter from Shōtoku Taishi, who governed Japan as Regent (a position similar to that of Vice President in America today) ; the meaning of the sentence is "I, Emperor (Son of Heaven) of the land from which the sun emerges, send this letter to the Emperor of the land where the sun goes down. How are things with you?"

LINE.translation: The Emperor of China, who was proud that his country was biggest and most powerful in the world at that time, was very angered when he heard the letter.

LINE.translation: This story is handed down as an event which showed that Japan could carry on relations on an equal basis even with a country as large as China. This raised the pride and deepened the patriotism of the people.

STORY.LINE:
この話は、日本が中国のような大きな国とでも対等に交際ができるようになったことをよく表しており、国民のプライドを高め、愛国心を深めるできごととして伝えられています。

LINE.translation: It is also said that the change in the name of Japan from Yamato, which had been the name to that point, to Nihon [origin of the sun] resulted from this incident.

STORY.LINE:

LINE.translation: In addition to this, Shōtoku Taishi enacted many new domestic policies.

LINE.translation: He reformed the method of advancement for officials, which had been entirely hereditary, adopting a twelve-step rank system in order that people of true ability would achieve high status.

STORY.LINE:

LINE.translation: He also established the seventeen-article constitution, said to be Japan's first constitution, so that officials could correctly observe regulations and laws.

STORY.LINE:

LINE.translation: He also attempted to govern the country on the basis of Buddhist teachings, as illustrated by the first article of the constitution which states, "Diligently honor Buddhism."

STORY.LINE:
また、この憲法の一条に「あつく仏教を敬え。」とあるように、仏の教えを基に国を治めようとしました。
また、この憲法の一条に「あつく仏教を敬え。」とあるように、仏の教えを基に国を治めようとしました。

LINE.translation: It is said that Hōryūji Temple, which still exists in Nara as the oldest wooden structure in the world, was built by Shōtoku Taishi in honor of his father, Emperor Yōmei.

STORY.LINE:

LINE.translation: In addition to that, he wrote "Sangyōgisho," a commentary on the Buddhist scriptures making them easy to understand, and attempted to teach Buddhism to large numbers of people.

STORY.LINE:
このほか、仏教の経典をわかりやすく説明した「三経義疏」という解説書も書いて、仏教を多くの人に教えようとしました。

LINE.translation: It was in this manner that Shōtoku Taishi attempted to create a better Japan, not only as a statesman, but as a man of religion and as a scholar.

STORY.LINE:
このように、政治家としてだけでなく宗教家として、また学者として、より良い日本を造り上げようと努力したのが聖徳太子です。

LINE.translation: Before he died he was called Umayado Toyotomimi no Ōji (Prince of the Stable whose ears hear all) by the people.

LINE.translation: I feel this story is interesting because it has many points that greatly resemble the story of Jesus in Christianity, which says that Christ was born in a stable and at the age of 12 was more intelligent than scholars of his day.

STORY.LINE:

GRAMMAR.english:
Even though we claim 〜

This structure comes from a more common structure 〜ても, even if. Often, 〜 is a general statement.

EXAMPLE.translation: You might say she is pretty, but she is not as beautiful as Cleopatra.

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: きれいだと言ってもクレオパトラほどじゃない。

GRAMMAR.english:
It is better to call it something 〜; We might (could) call it〜

This structure comes from 〜た方がいい: It is better to 〜. 言うhere is more general, although the whole sentence is a very subjective statement. 例. ディズニーランドは子供の遊園地と言うよりも大人の遊園地とでも言った方がいい。 Disneyland could just as easily be called an amusement park for adults as one for children.
GRAMMAR.LINK: お屋敷とでも言った方がいい

GRAMMAR.english:
It is nothing more than N; only N

〜 is usually a noun or a noun phrase, but can be a sentence.

EXAMPLE.translation: This is just my personal opinion, but I would think that it might be impossible to do that.

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: これはたんに私の個人の意見に過ぎませんが、それをするのは無理ではないかと思われます。

EXAMPLE.translation: Even though they say they can read kanji, all they can read are simple characters.

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: 漢字ができると言ってもやさしいのが少し読めるに過ぎない。

GRAMMAR.english:
as far as (to that extent); even

〜 is usually a noun or a noun phrase, for this usage, meaning “even.”

EXAMPLE.translation: Do you have to resort to those kinds of things?

EXAMPLE.translation: Will even you say things like that?

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: きみまでそんなことを言うのか。

GRAMMAR.english:
N can; as for N (potential or existence)

This structure is called “dative に.” When the predicate indicates “potential” or “existence,” the noun that can do or exists can be marked with に.

EXAMPLE.translation: There is no way he can read Latin.

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: あの人にラテン語が読めるわけがない。

EXAMPLE.translation: I don't know that much about it (I can't understand it well.)

GRAMMAR.english:
in-sentence question

This の is sometimes called “extended predicate” and usually refers to the reason or explanation.

EXAMPLE.translation: Please tell me why you quit your job.

GRAMMAR.english:
as (adj, adv) as possible; as much as possible

なるべく modifies predicates; hence, 〜 is usually an adjective, an adverb, or a verb. It often goes with an expression of volition, request, command, or suggestion.

EXAMPLE.translation: Please come as quickly as possible.

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: なるべく早く来て下さい。

GRAMMAR.english:
probably; 〜 , right?

This structure comes from a rhetorical question: 〜, isn't that right? It is a desire to express some uncertainty of the speaker.“Probably” is the closest to an English equivalent. It is often followed by the expression“思われます.” 例. 日本の世の中はこれからもますます変わって行くのではないか。 I think that Japanese society will probably continue to change even more.
GRAMMAR.LINK: 見あたらないのではないか

GRAMMAR.english:
surely

きっと is an adverb expressing the conjecture of the speaker. It calls for predicates which often show the speaker’s opinion such as でしょう, 〜に違いない.

EXAMPLE.translation: Surely I will do it.

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: きっとやってみせます。

EXAMPLE.translation: He certainly must be sleepy.

GRAMMAR.english:
manner; style

In order to understand this pattern, you must know another related pattern: 〜ふりをする "to put on airs," as in 先生のふりをする "Act as if [you] are a teacher," 寝たふりをする "Act as if [you] were asleep," 知らないふりをする "Pretend like [you] don’t know," or 元気なふりをする "Pretend like [I] am fine," etc. V (Base II) ぶり is a noun (pseudonoun) indicating a manner of a style in which the verb is performed. ふり becomes ぶり because V (Base II) is considered a noun and two nouns combined become a compound noun. The initial voiceless obstruent of the second noun in the compound noun becomes voiced as in 生活ぶり.

EXAMPLE.translation: What a beautiful style of writing!

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: なんと美しい書きぶりでしょう。

EXAMPLE.translation: According to the way he spoke, he suffered a great deal.

GRAMMAR.EXAMPLE: 彼の話しぶりによると、大分苦労したようだ。

GRAMMAR.english:
must be 〜

This structure expresses a strong conjecture on the part of the speaker. 例. 山ではもう雪がふったに違いない。 It must have already snowed in the mountains.

This structure is used to express the feeling or impression of the speaker. Often it is something uncertain or contrary to the fact, but the speaker feels as though something were happening.
